posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked:
I know CTRE sells #4 stud size ring connectors that can work with the CAN connection screw on a Kraken - just wondering if any of you have used a different source, maybe one with heat shrink?

(I’ve used Wirefy brand off Amazon for the 10 AWG power connection for Krakens, but can’t seem to find something I’m certain is the right footprint for the Kraken CAN #4 connection)

posts.name: Michael Cameron
posts.cooked:
Ferrules Direct ( CAN ):

VINYL (PVC) INSULATED RING TERMINALS  Ring terminals offer a tight and secure connection in high vibration areas. Simply crimp the ring terminals to your stranded wires to be attached to studs or posts. Vinyl Insulated ring terminals come in a...

link_counts.title: 22-16 AWG PVC Vinyl Insulated Ring Terminals, #4 Stud, Butted Seam, 100 Pieces - RV1-32 | Ferrules Direct

posts.name: Jan
posts.cooked:
We’ve purchased ours from McMaster ( CAN ): McMaster-Carr

Power: McMaster-Carr

I haven’t seen many with heat-shrink already installed, we just use some small 2:1 or 3:1 heatshrink to cover the end of the connector.

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked:
Thanks

Yeah - I have enough heat shrink for these, just was trying to save a second or two per connection with heat shrink already part of the terminal.

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked:
Thanks - have you used these? (Probably or you wouldn’t have posted about them?)

I see the store is in Sterling, VA - driving distance for me, and I need them ASAP

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
JBENJI:

I see the store is in Sterling, VA - driving distance for me, and I need them ASAP

You may want to call to make sure the store allows local pick up before heading out.

Would these work for you? You may want to check if your local Home Depot store has them in stock.

https://www.homedepot.com/p/Gardner-Bender-22-16-AWG-4-6-Stud-Ring-Terminal-Vinyl-Red-10-Pack-15-101/205846703

I had some bad experiences with crimp lugs purchased through Amazon, so now only purchase them from “suppliers to those who make their living using those parts”. They would not hold on the wire properly because the metal was significantly thinner than the ones I had purchased from Home Depot and the metal was significantly softer. YMMV.

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked:
Thanks - Yup, buyer beware when buying stuff from Amazon or other places, might not be suitable for the rigors of robotics. The speced thickness for the ones from Ferrules Direct is the same as the ones you can get from CTRE .

Anyway - I called the local Ferrules Direct and they do have local store pickup.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: +1 for Ferrules Direct. I got the uninsulated ones (which we heatshrink) and got them from 22-16 AWG Non Insulated Ring Terminals, #4 Stud, UL Approved, 100 Pieces - RNB1-3.2 | Ferrules Direct (and also the power version at 12-10 AWG Non Insulated Ring Terminals, #6 Stud, UL Approved, 100 Pieces - RNB5-37 | Ferrules Direct ). Have better crimp quality and inspect-ability with the uninsulated connectors.

link_counts.title: 22-16 AWG Non Insulated Ring Terminals, #4 Stud, UL Approved, 100 Pieces - RNB1-3.2 | Ferrules Direct
12-10 AWG Non Insulated Ring Terminals, #6 Stud, UL Approved, 100 Pieces - RNB5-37 | Ferrules Direct

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked: Good point about crimping - these are cheap enough that I went ahead and bought the non insulated ones after I bought the insulated ones. I’ve got about 27 miles of heat shrink…

posts.name: Ryan Reed
posts.cooked:
We use these for CAN (2x 22awg wires is equivalent to a 19awg wire, so it does actually fit properly): https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/te-connectivity-amp-connectors/61386-1/665781

Note that it needs a kind of weird crimp tool, not sure it’s worth doing unless you really want custom cables and the added benefit of the insulation crimp is worth it to you.

And these for power (butted seam not brazed, so can be used with a large open barrel crimper like the IWS-5100A): https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/te-connectivity-amp-connectors/34892/333498

Not really supposed to be used this way but it does a really good job

Apparently that is how they are supposed to be used. The official tool for the “budget” series looks like an open barrel crimper. Guess I’m not very original.

link_counts.title: 61386-1 TE Connectivity AMP Connectors | Connectors, Interconnects | DigiKey

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
You may find that insulated terminals are too tall/thick to allow the cover to be installed.  I think that’s why CTRE uses heat shrink.

Plus, honestly, I don’t love the crimpability/reliablility of insulated terminals. Bare copper you can really get after it…  Plastic in the way, not so much.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked: We used both of these Ferrules Direct parts (RNB1-3.2 and RNB5-37) with good success this year as well, and will likely continue to buy them.  We did buy right-color heat shrink so once assembled it’s all nice and presentable.  We used an Iwiss IWS-6 crimp tool , which handles both sizes.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: iCrimp Non-insulated Terminal Crimping Tool for AWG 16 to AWG 10 Non-Insulated Terminals and Butt/Spice/Open/Plug Connectors for Auto Electrical,Marine,Motorcycle Wiring Repairs,Loom Assembly : Automotive

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: I’m with you. Not clear what it is about the insulated, but when I trained new students on doing them, out of a dozen connections they did, I’d be able to pull out a few. Can’t recall any issues on the uninsulated. And this is with the correct quality ratcheting crimpers for both. The smaller heat shrink plus non-insulated looks better, too!

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked:
I see this threads been resurrected… So just a quick update - the uninsulated Ferrules Direct RNB1-3.2 worked perfectly for us - the insulated version, not so much (like others stated here, crimping with the insulation can be iffy)

Doubly perfect for us given we have a local Ferrules Direct store pickup ocation.
